docs.snippet: 64 years after the devastating 1950 World Cup, Maracanã stadium will host another final. Can the home team erase the memory of what happened there the last time?...
docs.lead_paragraph: 64 years after the devastating 1950 World Cup, Maracanã stadium will host another final. Can the home team erase the memory of what happened there the last time?
docs.abstract: Maracana Stadium in Rio de Janiero hosted historic loss for the Brazilian national team in 1950 World Cup, and is set to host the final of the World Cup in 2014.

headline.main: This Is What a Cursed Soccer Stadium Looks Like

docs.snippet: People don’t have to be displaced and workers don’t need to die for soccer....
docs.lead_paragraph: People don’t have to be displaced and workers don’t need to die for soccer.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Dave Zirin observes that FIFA, organization that oversees international soccer, is plagued by scandals concerning corruption, graft and excess as the 2014 World Cup is set to begin in Brazil; contends that world is finally seeing organization as stateless conglomerate that takes bribes while enabling world leaders to use World Cup to push through their development agendas; calls for abolishing FIFA.

headline.main: Throw FIFA Out of the Game
headline.print_headline: Throw FIFA Out of the Game

docs.snippet: There are rising doubts about FIFA’s ability to protect the World Cup tournament from the threat of match fixing....
docs.lead_paragraph: There are rising doubts about FIFA’s ability to protect the World Cup tournament from the threat of match fixing.
docs.abstract: Editorial raises doubts about ability of FIFA, soccer's world governing body, to protect the World Cup tournament from the rising threat of match fixing; notes untold millions in bets will be on the line; maintains FIFA owes it to world community and fans to keep matches clean.

docs.snippet: What does the greatest player in the world have to do to make Argentina love him?...
docs.lead_paragraph: What does the greatest player in the world have to do to make Argentina love him?
docs.abstract: Lionel Messi has never won widespread devotion in Argentina, where he lived until he was 13, despite fact that he has been chosen by FIFA as the best player in the world an unprecedented four of the last five years and he is widely considered one of the greatest soccer players ever.

docs.lead_paragraph: The captain of Brazil’s 2006 FIFA Club World Cup champions, Fernando Lúcio da Costa, better known as Fernandão, died early Saturday in a helicopter crash, his former team said.
